title: 'It's a huge achievement just to return safely': Son Heung-min opens up on 'aggressive' Korean derby
text:
Tottenham star Son Heung-min has described South Korea's World Cup qualifying match with North Korea as 'very aggressive' after the secretive clash ended goalless.

The historic encounter at the Kim II-Sung Stadium on Tuesday saw South Korean spectators and journalists banned from attending the game, while there was also no live broadcast of the match.

The Korea Football Association, based in Seoul, was allowed to send two staff to observe the match, who were able to tweet out updates as the match progressed.

South Korea and North Korea players confront each other on the pitch during Tuesday's clash

Substitutes are told to return to the bench as emotions run high between the two teams

South Korea captain Son Heung-min described the World Cup qualifier as 'very aggressive'

No fighting in front of the kids! Oh, but there are none here today.🤣 Emotions run high at times as #DPRK meets #ROK in #FIFA game - but audience is sparse. pic.twitter.com/HKaoKH89sj — Joachim Bergström (@jchmbrgstrm) October 15, 2019

North Korea, who are currently ranked 113th in the world, managed to take points off their southern neighbours in a result that saw two yellow cards dished out for each side.

And Son has revealed just how intense the game was after flying home on Thursday morning.

'It's too bad that we didn't win, but the match was very aggressive to a degree that I think it's a huge achievement just to return safely without being injured,' Son told reporters.

Son Heung-min (right) catches an arm to the face from North Korea's Ri Yong Chol (left)

The Tottenham star was unable to make an impact up front in the goalless stalemate

The Korean FA was given access to pictures and footage before leaving North Korea

'North Korean players were sensitive and aggressive. There was a lot of severe swearing.'

The 27-year-old also said he wasn't shocked to have played in an empty stadium.

Choi Young-il, the vice president of the Korea Football Association, also criticised how North Korea conducted themselves during the goalless encounter.

'It was like war. I've never seen such [aggression] in football until now,' he said.

Meanwhile, South Korea's coach Paulo Bento hit out at his own side's performance.

Son (right) and his South Korea team-mates arrive at Incheon airport early on Thursday

'It wasn't a good match at all. We didn't execute what we'd prepared,' Bento told reporters.

'We didn't have a great first half in particular, and the opponents held us in check. We got better in the second half, but there were too many stoppages of play because of the referee.'

The game was the first competitive meeting between the national men's teams in the North Korean capital, although the North hosted the South for a friendly in 1990.

The second match between the Koreas is scheduled for June 4 next year in South Korea.
description: The historic encounter at the Kim II-Sung Stadium in Pyongyang saw South Korean spectators and journalists banned from attending the game, while there was also no live broadcast of the match.
